description:
Population trends of Pacific Lamprey are inextricablyctied to their ocean prey.  However, it is uncertain which prey they utilize, how prey composition differs across space and time at sea, and whether Pacific Lamprey geographic origins associate with
variation in prey species. 

The objective of this study is to use metabarcoding genetic analysis to determine the composition of ocean-prey fishes based on the digested contents of the guts from Pacific Lamprey collected from ocean surveys and in-river sites.  Deliverables of this study include species identification of fish remnants in the gut contents of 50 individual Pacific Lamprey from each of 4 sites (West Coast commercial Pacific hake and Groundfish fisheries, Willamette Falls, and Bonneville Dam) based on mitochondrial
barcodes.  Percent species composition for each site will be calculated across all 50 individuals to estimate relative
abundance of each prey species.  Size of the individuals (a proxy for age) caught in the ocean will be used to determine
whether length of time spent in the ocean is associated with composition of prey fishes.  Finally, genetic stock
identification of each Pacific Lamprey individual will be used to test for an association of the composition of prey fishes with geographic region of origin.  The results of this study are relevant to all RMUs because Pacific Lamprey migrate from all RMUs and form a mixed stock in the ocean.  The sampling for this research requires “on-the-ground” focus in the Pacific Ocean RMU, Willamette RMU, and Mainstem Columbia RMU.
title: Willamette Falls Pacific Lamprey Gut Contents Monitoring
